Dedicated to the 100th anniversary of Chemistry at Nankai University Graphical abstract This review gives the insights into the various strategies of defect/interface engineering of high-efficiency electrocatalysts for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR). Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) under ambient conditions is an emerging strategy to tackle the hydrogen- and energy-intensive operations for traditional Haber-Bosch process in industrial ammonia (NH3) synthesis. However, the e-NRR performance is currently impeded by the inherent inertness of N2 molecules, the extremely slow kinetics and the overwhelming competition from the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), all of which cause unsatisfied yield and ammonia selectivity (Faradaic efficiency, FE). Defect and interface engineering are capable of achieving novel physical and chemical properties as well as superior synergistic effects for various electrocatalysts. In this review, we first provide a general introduction to the NRR mechanism. We then focus on the recent progress in defect and interface engineering and summarize how defect and interface can be rationally designed and functioned in NRR catalysts. Particularly, the origin of superior NRR catalytic activity by applying these approaches was discussed from both theoretical and experimental perspectives. Finally, the remaining challenges and future perspectives in this emerging area are highlighted. It is expected that this review will shed some light on designing NRR electrocatalysts with excellent activity, selectivity and stability. Keywords Nitrogen reduction Electrocatalysis Defect engineering Interface engineering Ambient conditions 1 Introduction Nitrogen is one of the basic elements of living matter and is closely related to human life [1]. Although nitrogen gas accounts for about 78 vol% of the atmosphere, it exists in its diatomic form (N2), which is not available to most flora [2]. The conversion of nitrogen to ammonia is essential because ammonia can be utilized in a wide range of applications. Besides the application as a raw material for agricultural production, ammonia can also be used in pharmaceuticals, dyes, textile, etc., and is one of the most important chemicals in industrial production [3–5]. Moreover, ammonia can be used in the field of energy conversion. Ammonia has been regarded as a portable and carbon–neutral energy carrier with high energy density and can play a significant role in the future hydrogen economy [6,7]. Therefore, fixation of earth-abundant nitrogen gas (N2) into ammonia is a key biochemical transformation which is required to sustain life. In nature, biological N2 fixation occurs under mild conditions via nitrogenase enzymes in specific bacteria [8,9]. However, the natural process could not satisfy the industrial demand. Until the early 20th century, the invention of the Haber-Bosch process caused a fundamental change in the global nitrogen cycle. Typically, ammonia is artificially synthesized through the Haber-Bosch process (N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3), in which high temperature (300–500 °C), extremely high pressure (150–300 atm), and high-purity nitrogen and hydrogen gases are required [10]. As a result, it is estimated that this process accounts for approximately 1%–3% of annual global energy consumption and substantial greenhouse gas emissions [11,12]. Obviously, this process is not economical and environmentally friendly in the long run. It is therefore of great importance to develop a carbon–neutral and sustainable route for NH3 synthesis to tackle the fossil energy crisis and global warming. In the past few years, various alternative approaches have been investigated to realize low-cost artificial nitrogen fixation, including biochemical catalysis, photocatalysis, thermal catalysis, and electrocatalysis [13–17]. Among various strategies of fixing N2, electrochemical reduction of N2 is particularly promising due to its unique advantages of utilizing of electric energy that comes from renewable solar and wind energy and using proton directly from water as the hydrogen source [11,18,19]. Therefore, the development of electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is of great significance for adjusting the energy structure, alleviating the energy crisis and resolving the environmental problems. The most significant bottleneck of NH3 synthesis is the intrinsic inertness of diatomic N2, which owns a highly intensive NN bond and thus lacks a permanent dipole as well as the low solubility in aqueous solutions [20–22]. Besides, the current progress in electrochemical NRR is impeded by the overwhelming competition from the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) due to the preferential adsorption of H atom over N atom on almost all traditional NRR catalysts (including Fe, Ru and Co) [23,24]. Consequently, the majority of NRR studies report low ammonia yield and Faradic efficiency. To date, a number of NRR electrocatalysts that are based on noble-metals (e.g., Au, Ru, Rh, Pt, Ag, Pd) [25–32], transition-metal sulfides, carbides, nitrides, oxides (e.g., MoS2, Fe3S4, Mo2C/C, V2O3/C, VN, Mo2N, WO3, Nb2O5, TiO2) [33–44], and metal-free materials (e.g., B, C, N, Cl, F) [45–50] have been developed and widely noted. Despite the encouraging advances, the NRR activity and selectivity are still far from satisfactory. In order to enhance the NRR performance, it is extremely necessary to optimize the whole electrochemical system, including the cell configuration, electrolyte, and electrocatalysts [51]. Notably, in an electrochemical NRR system, the electrocatalysts play the vital role in accelerating the reaction rate and improving the selectivity/efficiency. To achieve high-selectivity and high-performance NRR at ambient conditions, the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts that can activate the inert NN bond, expedite their dissociation and retard the competing HER is urgently required. Generally, there are two aspects to improve the activity when designing electrocatalysts: increasing the apparent activity or promoting the intrinsic activity [52]. From the former aspect, the apparent activity of electrocatalysts always depends on the number of exposed electrochemically active sites. From the latter aspect, the intrinsic activity is associated with the activity of the active site, which is influenced by the electronic structure of electrocatalysts. The rational design of catalysts, such as introducing various vacancies and heteroatom, constructing a specific structure, exposing active crystal facets, amorphization and fabricating novel heterointerface, could be considered as effective ways to improve the apparent activity and/or promote the intrinsic activity [53–60]. In addition, other strategies, such as changing the electrolytes, enhancing mass transfer rates, and designing specific electrolytic system, could also be beneficial for high NRR performance [61–63]. In past decades, the above-mentioned strategies have been successfully applied to the design of heterogeneous electrocatalysts in applications such as HER [64], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [65], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [66], and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [67]. Recently, the strategy of defect and interface engineering has emerged as an effective way for boosting the electrocatalytic NRR performance, and studies on this aspect become a hot topic in the field. Defects can be regarded as any inhomogeneous composition in a material, which are widely present on a large variety of materials [67]. Although most materials have intrinsic defects, the catalytic activity mainly relies on the introduced ones. Doping, controlled etching, and growth, decreasing size and pretreatment are effective methods to fabricate defective electrocatalysts [68]. The most frequently discussed type of defects in heterogeneous catalysis mainly include vacancy, heteroatom doping, amorphization and so on. Unlike the defect-free catalysts, defects have potential to significantly regulate and modify the local coordination environment of electrocatalysts, which could be considered as effective strategies to promote the catalytic performance [69]. Interface, referred to as the boundary of two different components, has been proven to exhibit unique properties compared to individual component [70]. According to the material types, interface can be classified into different categories. Since the majority of NRR electrocatalysts are metallic, interfaces between metal and other types of materials such as metal oxides and carbon material are wildly exploited. Interface engineering could substantially enhance the overall catalytic activities and stabilities because the strong interfacial interaction could establish abundant channels with high electron transport speed and highly preserve exposed active sites, thus improving the activity via promoting the electron transfer and optimizing the free energies of important intermediates. Indeed, all these changes in electronic structures of catalyst surface and subsurface atoms are vital for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction, where new or distinct active sites for N2 adsorption and activation can be introduced. Considering the rapid development of electrocatalytic NRR field over the past few years, it is necessary to summarize and discuss the progress in this aspect for guiding the design of high-performance NRR catalysts. Motivated by such facts, this review mainly focuses on the rational design of NRR electrocatalysts for achieving high ammonia yield and high Faradaic efficiency via defect and interface engineering. Herein we begin with a brief introduction of the mechanism of the electrocatalytic NRR (e-NRR). Subsequently, we provide a comprehensive and detailed review on defect and interface engineering for e-NRR electrocatalysts, emphasizing the elucidation of active sites and intrinsic mechanisms. We will discuss how the defect (vacancies, heteroatom-doping, single-atom, crystal facet, amorphization) engineering and the surface (metal–metal oxide interface, metal–carbon material interface, intermetallic compounds from the viewpoint of alloyed structure, gas-electrolyte-catalyst interface) regulation alter the number of active sites or the electronic structure and then promote the activity of NRR electrocatalysts (Fig. 1 ). In the final section, we summarize the present research status and challenges from different aspects in this emerging field and provide prospects into the potential strategies to develop more advanced NRR electrocatalysts. We hope that this review will become provocative and assist researchers to create more efficient catalysts for electrochemical NRR. 2 Fundamental principles of e-NRR 2.1 Thermodynamics of e-NRR Theoretically, electrochemical reduction of N2 to NH3 can take place under mild conditions, whereby the thermodynamic driving force is controlled by the external voltage [71]. However, the inertness of this nonpolar molecule is well known and the NRR process is suppressed by the sluggish splitting of the stable triple bond. The N2 molecule has a high triple bond energy of 941 kJ mol−1, hence significant energy is required to break the NN bond (Fig. 2 a). The cleavage of the first bond requires an energy higher than 410 kJ mol−1, which is almost half of the NN bond energy, resulting in a large challenge in the dissociation of the N2 molecule [72]. Besides, the direct protonation is thermodynamically forbidden for dinitrogen owing to the endothermic process for the addition of the first-H (ΔH0 = 37.6 kJ mol−1). The intrinsically inert properties of N2 molecule is also characterized by a very high ionization energy (15.8 eV) and negative electron affinity (−1.9 eV), which reduces the reactivity of nitrogen [22]. From a kinetic perspective, the N2 molecule has a large energy gap (10.8 eV) between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) (Fig. 2b) [72], which is unfavorable for the electron transfer processes and Lewis acid/base reactions. On the other hand, the electrocatalytic NRR process is challenging because the competing HER is always dominant in the electrochemical reaction. The related equilibrium potentials with either normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), or reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) as reference are provided in Table 1 [73]. The electrocatalytic NRR involves multiple proton-electron transfer reactions and different intermediates. As illustrated in R1, R2, R3 and R4, the theoretical potentials of NRR are comparable to that of the competing HER no matter it is under acidic or alkaline conditions. Nevertheless, the NRR process involves six electrons while HER only requires two, revealing that multiple proton/electron participated process are required to accomplish NRR. Consequently, majority of the electrons/protons would preferably participate in HER, which can explain why hydrogen gas is the main by-product for the NRR process. As illustrated in R5, the relatively negative redox potentials for the N2H intermediate clarify that the initial H atom addition process is tough. Clearly, these unfavorable potentials indicate that the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction is thermodynamically difficult. Table 2. Table 3. 2.2 Mechanism of e-NRR Like other catalytic processes, the e-NRR consists of three basic steps: (i) the adsorption of N2 molecules (N2 + * → *N2, where * denotes an adsorption site on catalyst surface) and the subsequent activation on the active centers at the surface of the catalyst; (ii) the NN triple bond cleavage and hydrogenation, including *N2 + e− + H+ → *NNH, *NNH + e− + H+ → *NHNH, *NHNH + e− + H+ → *NHNH2, *NHNH2 + e− + H+ → *NH2NH2, *NH2NH2 + e− + H+ → *NH2 + NH3, *NH2 + e− + H+→NH3+*; (iii) the generated NH3 molecules (or other intermediates) desorbed from the catalyst surface. In the electrocatalytic process, the hydrogenation of the dinitrogen molecule is completed by continuous proton-electron transfer reactions. According to the different sequence of the hydrogenation process and the cleavage of the NN triple bond, it is generally believed that the e-NRR may follows two mechanisms: (i) dissociative pathway and (ii) associative pathway (Fig. 2c) [71]. According to the dissociative pathway, the stable NN bond is cleaved prior to the hydrogenation process after nitrogen is adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. The two generated N atoms are then separately hydrogenated until NH3 is formed and finally desorbed from the catalyst surface. The industrial Haber-Bosch process usually follows the dissociative pathway. Harsh conditions are required since the cleavage of the inert triple NN needs a high energy input. However, in the associative pathway, the NN bond is gradually cleaved with the simultaneous hydrogenation process on each N atom. Considering different hydrogenation sequences on each N atom, the associative pathway can be further generalized into the distal pathways and alternating pathways. In the distal pathway, the remote nitrogen atom preferentially undergoes the hydrogenation and released the remote NH3 molecule; whereas in the alternating pathway, the two N atoms are hydrogenated simultaneously and two NH3 molecules are released sequentially. Therefore, the by-product N2H4 can only be formed as a reaction intermediate in the alternating pathway. Notably, the desorption of *N2H4 on the catalyst surface is a strong endothermic process, so in most cases the NRR only produces a small amount of N2H4. Compared to the dissociation path, the cleavage of the NN triple bond is not required in the association path, which greatly reduces the energy input in the N2 reduction reaction. As a result, the electrocatalytic NRR is mostly carried out through the association mechanism. Notably, there is another associative pathway, namely the enzymatic pathway. During the enzymatic pathway, both N atoms are anchored on the catalyst surface with a special side-on adsorption mode, different from an end-on adsorption mode of N atoms presented on most heterogeneous catalyst surfaces [73,74]. Recently, Abghoui and Skúlason proposed that the NRR pathway on transition metal nitrides (TMNs) can be explained by a unique Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [75]. Different from the above-mentioned dissociative and associative pathways, in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, the first NH3 molecule is generated through the hydrogenation process of the lattice N atoms on the surface of the TMNs, leaving N vacancies at the same time. Theses N vacancies are restored by the N2 dissolved in the electrolyte and reduced to generate the second NH3 molecule, thus completing the catalytic cycle process. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation revealed that the overpotential for N2 reduction is smaller via MvK mechanism than that via associative mechanism. Therefore, the new MvK mechanism might be favorable for e-NRR on TMNs catalysts and presents a new perspective to understand the N2 reduction. Recently, combined with detailed density functional theory calculations, quantitative 14N/15N isotope exchange experiments confirmed that the e-NRR on VN indeed follows the MvK mechanism [76]. Theoretical calculations, as a widely used tool, are of great significance to further understand the fundamental mechanisms of electrochemical NRR. Especially, the DFT calculations can elucidate the reaction pathway by determining and comparing the Gibbs reaction energies from different reaction pathways [77]. In addition, theoretical methods are an important tool to explain the trends in catalytic activity and screen active catalysts. For example, based on DFT calculations of early-transition-metal surfaces, Nørskov and co-workers established the correlation between the theoretical limiting potentials and the binding energy of N adatoms on selected transition metal surfaces [10]. According to the Volcano-shaped plots, Mo, Fe, Ru, and Rh (on the top side of the volcano plots) are expected to show the highest catalytic activity for NRR. However, they are also active for the HER, resulting a low Faraday efficiency in the ammonia production. For those metals on the right side of the volcano plots, relatively negative potentials are required and the surfaces of these metal are prone to be covered with H atoms rather than N atoms. Importantly, Sc, Y, Ti and Zr (on the left side of the volcano plots) are prefer to bond with the N atom than with the H atom. These metals can be used as suitable NRR catalysts. However, the surface of these metals is easily oxidized. Therefore, a combined theoretical and experimental methods is critical to accelerate the catalyst screening process and to manufacture efficient electrocatalysts for selective e-NRR. 2.3 Effect of defects and interface in e-NRR To tackle the bottlenecks in e-NRR, numerous efforts have been dedicated to promote the catalytic performance. Notably, electrocatalysis is a surface-sensitive process, and the surface and subsurface configuration directly affect the catalytic activity [78–81]. Among all properties of catalyst surface, defects and interfaces are the most extensively engineered. Engineering the defect and interface of electrocatalysts is an effective strategy for optimizing their catalytic activities toward various electrochemical reactions [82–86]. It is also expected that these strategies could significantly improve the NRR activity under ambient conditions. The most commonly used strategies for fabricating/engineering defect and interface are summarized in Fig. 3 . Defects exist in a large variety of materials, and the types of defects mainly include vacancy, heteroatom-doping, single-atom, crystal facet control, and amorphization. Engineering the defects is an effective strategy to regulate the local coordination environment of electrocatalysts and enable unconventional adsorption behaviors of reactants on the catalyst surface, thus enhancing the intrinsic activity of the catalysts [87]. For example, vacancies can simultaneously tailor the electronic states and optimize the reaction pathway, leading to enhanced binding capability for N2 fixation, lower energy barrier, and superior NRR performances [88,89]. Apart from the vacancy engineering, heteroatom-doping is another effective strategy for enhancing the catalytic activity. The introduction of heteroatoms into original electrocatalysts could not only tune the surface electronic structure but also advantageously improve the adsorption abilities for reactants and intermediates [90]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have present new opportunities toward NRR due to the lowest site size, higher atom utilization efficiency, and unique low-coordinated features [91–93]. Rational control of crystal with desired faces at the atom-scale provides an efficient strategy for maximizing the exposure of active sites. Moreover, different exposed crystal facets can influence the adsorption and activation of N2 and intermediates on the catalyst surface, thus affecting the catalytic performance [94]. Compared to the crystalline counterpart, amorphization of an electrocatalyst enables a large increase of unsaturated coordination sites, rich defects, metastable state, abnormal local electronic structure, thereby affecting the activity and selectivity of electrocatalysts [95]. In the field of electrocatalysis, interface regulation provides a convenient way to generate novel physical and chemical properties and reasonably optimize the key limiting parameters of electrocatalyst [78]. Many studies have shown that interface engineering is an important method to effectively optimize electrocatalytic performance, because the strong interface interaction of different components can create high-speed electron transmission channels and simultaneously induce electronic coupling effects [96,97]. Through reasonable interface engineering, mainly including metal–metal oxide, metal (derivative)-carbon, and intermetallic interfaces, numerous high-performance catalysts have been explored for important electrocatalytic applications such as HER, oxygen evolution reaction, and CO2 reduction reaction [78,98]. Particularly, apart from the electrocatalysts, the NRR performance are also affected by the interface among gas, electrolyte and catalysts. Motivated by these facts, manipulating the formation of abundant interface could be a crucial and feasible way to solve dynamic issues in the NRR process. Defect and interface engineering can optimize the electronic states, raise the chemical adsorption capacity of N2 and intermediates, and reduce energy barrier of whole reactions, thus improving catalytic activity. In addition, the interface between different components can create more active centers than single component, stabilize the active sites, and produce unique synergistic effects. Therefore, defect and interface engineering have become an essential way to improve the activity, selectivity and stability of NRR catalysts, and are conducive to in-depth study of the reaction mechanism of electrocatalytic N2 fixation. To date, the exploration of defect and interface engineering in the NRR field is at an early stage but has exhibited much fruitful progress. 3 Defect engineering 3.1 Vacancy Introducing vacancies (e.g., O vacancies (OVs), N vacancies (NVs), S vacancies (SVs), and C vacancies (CVs)) into the structure can enhance the catalytic performance toward NRR via regulating the local electronegativity and coordination environment [99–102]. Notably, metal oxides are widely used in catalysis. The creation of oxygen vacancies in metal oxides can tailor the surface electronic properties, enhance reactant adsorption and activation, thereby affecting catalytic performance. For instance, Sun and co-workers systematically studied the e-NRR performance and mechanism of TiO2 with rich oxygen vacancies through theoretical calculations and experiments [103]. They tuned the OVs concentrations of TiO2 by regulating the annealing temperature. The samples annealed at 700, 800, and 900 °C were denoted as TiO2(Vo)_700, TiO2(Vo)_800, and TiO2(Vo)_900, respectively. The TiO2(Vo)_700 and TiO2(Vo)_800 both showed reflections of tetragonal anatase TiO2, whereas phase transformation from anatase to rutile occurred in the case of TiO2(Vo)_900. According the results of XRD, XPS and ESR (Fig. 4 a-c), TiO2(Vo)_800 exhibited the highest content of OVs. The electrochemical characterization indicated that the presence of OVs promotes the efficiency of nitrogen reduction. When tested in 0.1 M aqueous HCl, TiO2(Vo)_800 with the highest OVs content exhibited a NH3 yield of about 3.0 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and FE of 6.5% at −0.12 vs. RHE, outperforming the other two samples. DFT calculations (Fig. 4d) revealed that the surface oxygen vacancies in TiO2 not only activate the first protonation step but also increase N2 chemisorption (relative to *H), thus enhancing electrocatalytic NRR performance. As reported by Zeng and co-workers, Vo-LaCoO3 which contains abundant oxygen vacancies exhibited superior electrocatalytic NRR performance with an average ammonia yield of 182.2 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 (2.8 times higher than that of pure LaCoO3) at −0.7 vs. the RHE and Faradaic efficiency of 7.6% at −0.6 vs. RHE under ambient conditions [104]. DFT calculations demonstrated that the OVs played a critical role in increasing the charge density around the valence band edge, which could be conductive to N2 activation. Moreover, the analysis of the thermodynamic limiting potentials for N2 reduction and H2 evolution revealed the higher selectivity of Vo-LaCoO3 toward N2 electroreduction. Yan and co-workers successfully obtained a noble-metal-free catalyst OVs-BiVO4 with different concentrations of OVs by adjusting the pH via hydrothermal reaction [105]. The as-prepared OVs-BiVO4 with the highest OVs concentration exhibited excellent NRR performance, including high NH3 yield rate of 8.60 µg h−1 mgcat. −1, high FE (up to 10.04%) at −0.5 V vs. RHE, and good stability (up to 24 h). Owing to the introduction of OVs, the OVs-BiVO4 with lower coordination, higher spin-polarization, and a localized magnetic moment exhibited enhanced N2 adsorption energy and a more favorable active reaction site at the V atom, thus significantly improving the electrocatalytic performance of NRR. Inspired by the contribution of OVs to NRR performance, it is reasonable to assume that NVs would also exhibit potential in improving the activity for N2 fixation. Yu and coworkers obtained a metal-free polymeric carbon nitride (PCN) catalyst containing abundant nitrogen vacancies via facile polycondensation of melamine and further argon re-calcination [106]. The results of TEM, XPS, EPR and UV/vis DRS (Fig. 5 a–d) proved the presence of nitrogen vacancies and further speculated that the NVs are preferentially engineered at N2C (two-coordinated N) site as shown in Fig. 5(e). DFT calculations revealed that N2 molecules can be chemically adsorbed on the nitrogen vacancies of PCN and the NN bond length of adsorbed N2 increases from 1.0975 Å to 1.26 Å, corresponding to the “strong activation” system for effective conversion of N2 into NH3. The outstanding NRR performance of PCN-NV4 reached a FE of 11.59% and a high NH3 yield rate of 8.09 µg h−1 mgcat. −1 at a low potential of − 0.2 V vs. RHE (Fig. 5f–g), which is 10-fold higher than that of PCN without nitrogen vacancies. However, 15N2 isotopic experiments are required to prove that the N sources of detected ammonia generated from e-NRR rather than the nitrogen-containing electrocatalyst itself. It is noteworthy that the vacancy stability has a significant influence on the catalytic performance because the active sites might suffer from poisoning or deactivation during the NRR process. Recent advanced research has reported some strategies to tackle the stability problem of the NRR catalysts [107]. For instance, Chu and coworkers successfully synthesized S-NV-C3N4 as an efficient and durable NRR electrocatalyst via filling the NVs with S dopants in graphitic C3N4 [108]. They found that the S-NV-C3N4 exhibited a fascinating NRR performance with a FE of 14.1% and a NH3 yield of 32.7 µg h−1 mg−1 at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M LiClO4, together with the superior durability for at least 20 h, which were greatly outperforming NV-containing C3N4. Notably, a series of control experiments including 15N2 isotopic experiments were carried out to exclude the nitrogen contaminant exerted influence on the NRR results. DFT calculations disclosed that the filled S dopants could significantly optimize the adsorption of NRR intermediates and reduce reaction barrier, thus realizing in both high NRR activity and stability of the C3N4 catalyst. Qiao and coworkers obtained a new 2D layered W2N3 nanosheet with rich NVs through high temperature treatment of W2N3 nanosheets in a H2/Ar atmosphere [109]. The morphology of W2N3 changed little after treatment and remained the two-dimensional (2D) sheet-like structure, but its NRR electrocatalytic performance was significantly improved. Significantly, the designed catalyst showed high activity with an average NH3 formation rate of 11.66 µg h−1 mg−1 and a FE of 11.67% at −0.2 V vs. RHE. DFT calculations showed that the nitrogen vacancies on 2D W2N3 significantly reduce the energy barrier of the NRR reaction, and the electron-deficient environment induced by the NVs is extremely favorable conditions for the adsorption of nitrogen molecules. What's more, NVs possessed good stability due to the high valence state of tungsten atoms and the restriction effect of the two-dimensional layered structure, which have been proven by a series of ex situ characterizations. Due to comparable chemical properties between oxygen and sulfur, engineering sulfur vacancies (SVs) into the S-containing catalysts is also expected to afford excellent catalytic performance for the NRR [110–114]. Chen and coworkers prepared N-doped MoS2 nanoflowers with enhanced exposure of sulfur vacancies to act as an efficient NRR catalyst [112]. In 0.1 M Na2SO4, the optimized SV-rich N-doped MoS2 nanoflowers can achieve an excellent NH3 yield rate (69.82 µg h−1 mg−1) with high FE (9.14 %) at −0.3 V vs. RHE at room temperature and ambient pressure, outperforming those of the MoS2-based materials reported in the literature. The N-doping played an important role by creating rich sulfur vacancies and generating Mo-N active sites. Both surface structure characterizations and DFT calculations demonstrated that the presence of SVs could effectively promote electron transfer paths, which could be conductive to enhance N2 activation and improve the NRR activity. 3.2 Heteroatom doping Heteroatom doping can not only optimize the electronic structure of the catalyst surface, but also tune the adsorption properties of reactants or reaction intermediates. According to the type of heteroatoms, it can be divided into two types: nonmetal doping and metal doping. For nonmetal doping, N, S, O, B and P are usually selected as dopants [115,116]. In the field of e-NRR, the application of heteroatom doping is mainly focused on carbon-based materials, which have been successfully used to catalyze various electrochemical reactions due to their excellent electrical conductivity and large specific surface area [117,118]. Taking nitrogen doped carbon materials as an example, the doping of nitrogen can change the electronic structure of nearby carbon atoms and cause defects, so that the reactant molecules are more firmly adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The nitrogen content and species may be the key factors that determine nitrogen adsorption and ammonia synthesis. Zhao and coworkers synthesized a N-doped porous carbon (NPC) electrocatalyst with high NRR activity [119]. DFT calculations revealed that pyridinic and pyrrolic N were active sites. Therefore, increasing the content of pyridinic and pyrrolic N were essential for ammonia synthesis. The introduction of heteroatoms into the carbon material can substantially enhance their activity. For instance, Zheng and coworkers first reported boron-doped graphene as an efficient metal-free NRR electrocatalyst [120]. Since the electronegativity of B (2.04) is lower than that of C (2.55), the doping of B leads to a significant redistribution of electron density on the carbon ring structure. The positively charged B atoms are more favorable for the adsorption of nitrogen molecules and provide active centers for the formation of B-N bonds and subsequent protonation of nitrogen molecules. Meanwhile, the positively charged B atom further prevents the adsorption of H and thus inhibits the competition of HER. Both experiments and DFT calculations revealed that the graphene-like BC3 enabled the lowest energy barrier for NRR. The obtained catalyst achieved a high ammonia production rate of 9.8 µg h−1 cm−2 and a Faraday efficiency of 10.8% in 0.05 M H2SO4 electrolyte at −0.5 V vs. RHE. Similar to nonmetal doping, metal doping can also modify the electronic structure, optimize the absorption free energy of the intermediate, and improve the electrocatalytic activity. Considering that almost all nitrogenase enzymes have FeMo-based center, Fe was extensively used as the effective dopant to improve the electrochemical N2 reduction. Sun and coworkers first reported Fe-doped TiO2 electrocatalyst for highly efficient NRR [121]. XPS and TEM indicated that the Fe ions incorporated into the TiO2 lattice (Fig. 6 a and b). The Fe-doped TiO2 afforded a remarkable NH3 yield (25.47 µg h−1 mg−1) and a high FE (25.6%) at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M LiClO4, which were much higher than those of previously reported titanium- and iron-based NRR electrocatalysts in aqueous media (Fig. 6d). Additionally, the catalyst also showed high stability during the NRR process (Fig. 6e). DFT calculation illustrated that the introduction of Fe into TiO2 (101) spontaneously increases the concentration of oxygen vacancies and thus further promotes N2 activation (Fig. 6c). The synergistic effects of bi-Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies play an essential role in the enhanced catalytic performance. This work opens an exciting new avenue for the rational design of Fe-doped transition metal oxides for artificial N2 fixation with enhanced performance. At the same time, Liu and coworkers successfully prepared an Fe-doped and defect-rich W18O49 nanowire, which exhibited high electrocatalytic NRR activity [122]. In a N2-saturated 0.25 M LiClO4 aqueous solution, a large NH3 formation rate of 24.7 µg h−1 mgcat. −1 and a high FE of 20.0% were achieved at an overpotential of only 0.15 V vs. RHE. The experimental characterization combined with DFT calculations demonstrated that the intercalation-type doping of Fe atoms in the tunnels of the W18O49 crystal structure played a critical role in increasing the oxygen vacancies and exposing more W active sites, which can promote its N2 fixation ability and minimize the NRR overpotentials, serving as a trigger to facilitate the NRR process. Motivated by the fact that Mo can serve as the essential metal element in nitrogenases, the doping of Mo has also received significant interests for electrochemical conversion of N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions. Qiu and coworkers prepared the Mo-doped iron phosphide (Mo-FeP) nanosphere by thermal-assisted phosphorization as an efficient transition-metal-based catalyst for e-NRR [123]. Compared to original FeP, Mo doped FeP showed a higher electrocatalytic performance with an ammonia production rate of 13.1 µg h−1 mg−1 and a Faraday efficiency of 7.49% in 0.1 M HCl at −0.5 V and −0.2 V vs. RHE, respectively. Besides, the catalyst possessed excellent durability, stability, and repeatability for the e-NRR. The better catalytic performance might be due to the doping of Mo species, which is favorable for the polarization of N2 molecules and enables the NN triple bond dissociation. As reported by Chu’s group, Mo-doped MnO2 nanoflowers (Mo-MnO2 NFs) exhibited superior electrocatalytic NRR performance with average ammonia yield of 36.6 µg h−1 mg−1 and corresponding FE of 12.1% at −0.4 V vs. RHE at ambient conditions [124]. It was demonstrated that the multi-functional Mo dopants corresponded to the significantly NRR enhancement. As revealed by DFT calculations, the electron-deficient character of Mo dopants could not only enhance the conductivity of MnO2 but also activate the inert Mn sites for enhancing the intrinsic NRR activity of MnO2. Remarkably, the electron-deficient Mo results in superior electrostatic repulsion with protons, thus retarding the binding of Lewis acid H+ and suppressing the HER, giving rise to an effective N2 fixation. Heteroatom doping and vacancy engineering have been widely concerned as the most effective approaches to readily modulate the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts. Recently, advanced researches have demonstrated that these two approaches can be rationally combined to modulate the electrocatalytic NRR activity [125–127]. For instance, Chu and coworkers rationally combined heteroatom doping with SVs engineering to modulate SnS2 by Mo doping [128]. They found that Mo doping could induce the generation of enriched SVs. DFT calculations enclosed that the co-presence of the Mo dopant and SVs enabled the creation of Mo–Sn–Sn trimer active sites, which could strongly activate N2 and lower the reaction energy barrier. The as-prepared Mo-doped SnS2 nanosheets exhibited a significantly enhanced NRR activity with an NH3 yield of 41.3 µg h−1 mg−1 (−0.5 V vs. RHE) and a FE of 20.8% (−0.4 V vs. RHE). These works provide new insights into the synergistic role of heteroatom doping and vacancy engineering played in the NRR, which will open up new avenues for the design of high-performance NRR electrocatalysts. 3.3 Single atom In recent years, single atom catalysts (SACs) have become one of the most attractive candidates in various catalytic reactions due to their maximum atom utilization, unique electronic-geometric structure, and excellent catalytic performance. Applying the concept of single atoms to catalyst preparation is an effective way to improve the available active sites and reduce the catalyst cost. For single atom catalysts, nearly 100% atomic efficiency can increase the number of active sites while unsaturated active sites and enhanced metal support interaction can improve the intrinsic activity of active sites. The synergistic promotion of these two aspects is beneficial to improve the performance of the catalyst. Therefore, the construction of a single-atom catalyst is considered to be a promising way to enhance the catalytic activity of e-NRR. To date, numerous progress has been observed in the fabrication of various SACs, mainly focused on the noble-metal atoms (Ru [129–131], Au [132,133]), and non-noble metal atoms (Mo [134], Fe [135–140], Cu [141], Ni [142], and Mn [143]). With isolated single atoms dispersed on different supports, SACs exhibit outstanding catalytic performance compared with traditional heterogeneous catalysts. Considering the high surface energy, stabilizing the isolated single atoms against migration and aggregation is one of the key challenges during the preparation. Metal-organic framework (MOF) is an appropriate candidate for the preparation of single-atom catalysts, which composes of metal-containing nodes and organic linkers. By using MOFs as precursor, defect-rich carbon hosts via a pyrolysis of MOFs were created, which can trap metal precursors and stabilize isolated metal atoms during the following thermal activation. For example, Zeng and coworkers reported Ru SAs by distributing Ru on nitrogen-doped carbon (Ru SAs/N-C), which exhibited a record-high activity for N2 electrochemical reduction with the NH3 yield rate of 120.9 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and corresponding FE of 29.6% at −0.2 V vs. RHE [129]. Notably, Ru SAs/N-C was prepared via pyrolyzing the Ru-containing derivative of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF-8) and the single Ru atoms coordinated with N atoms kept atomically dispersed after NRR. DFT calculations revealed that the N2 dissociation (from *N2 to *NNH) exhibited the highest energy barrier among all the steps on either Ru SAs/N-C or Ru (101), serving as the rate-limiting step. Furthermore, the variation in Gibbs free-energy (ΔG) for N2 dissociation on Ru1-N3 and Ru1-N4 were lower than that on Ru (101). Compared with Ru nanoparticles, the Ru SAs/N-C presented a largely enhanced NRR performance with high efficiency. In recent years, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has also been found to be a superior support for SACs due to a high content of pyridine-like nitrogen which can provide rich electron lone pairs for anchoring single atoms within its ligands. Ma and coworkers synthesized a new g-C3N4-supported Ru single-atom (Ru SAs/g-C3N4) electrocatalyst toward electrochemical NRR in strong alkaline electrolytes at ambient conditions [131]. The as-synthesized Ru SAs/g-C3N4 possessed excellent catalytic activity with an NH3 yield rate of 23.0 µg mgcat. −1h−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 8.3% at 0.05 V vs. RHE, outperforming that of the bulk Ru counterpart. As revealed by DFT calculations, single-atom Ru possesses more favorable reaction thermodynamics of NRR due to its stronger N2 adsorption and reduced H poisoning at the reactive sites, thereby leading to the enhancement of catalytic activity. Besides noble-metal based SACs, non-noble metal catalysts have also received great attention in the NRR field due to their low cost and high electrocatalytic activity. For example, Hou and coworkers prepared an unusual NRR catalyst consisting of single Fe atoms anchored on a N,O-doped inverse opal carbon structure (FeSA-NO-C) (Fig. 7 a) [136]. Combining the X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) results, it proved that the Fe species are composed of predominantly isolated Fe atoms coordinated with two nitrogen and four oxygen atoms on the 3D N, O-codoped carbon structure (Fig. 7b–e). Further DFT calculations revealed that more electrons tend to be transferred from the Fe atom to the N2 molecule after the introduction of O species, which is favorable for the N2 activation. The free-energy diagram in Fig. 7(f) showed that the rate-determining step (*N2 → *NNH) energy barrier for FeSA-NO-C is much lower than that for FeSA-N4-C, indicating that the introduction of O atoms accelerates reaction kinetics, thus promoting the NRR activity (Fig. 7g). The as-synthesized FeSA-NO-C exhibited a superior high NH3 yield rate of 31.9 µg mgcat. −1h−1 and corresponding Faradaic efficiency of 11.8% at −0.4 V vs. RHE under ambient conditions. Notably, no obvious change was observed during 10 consecutive cycles, suggesting an excellent stability for FeSA-NO-C. This research provided a novel way for rational design of efficient metal-nitrogen-carbon electrocatalysts for a variety of electrochemical reactions. Xin and coworkers constructed single Mn-O3N1 sites anchored on porous carbon (Mn-O3N1/PC) via delicately controlling the Mn-O bonding conditions [143]. The experimental results showed that the as-synthesized Mn-O3N1/PC exhibited high electrocatalytic activity for NRR, with an NH3 yield of 66.41 µg mgcat. −1h−1 and a FE of 8.91% in 0.1 M HCl electrolyte, which was four times that of Mn-N4/PC catalyst. In addition, the catalyst had no obvious current drop and large FE fluctuation within 60 h, showing remarkable stability. Further DFT calculations revealed that the enhanced catalytic performance could be attributed to the unique geometry and electronic structures of Mn-O3N1, which could facilitate the adsorption and activation of the N2 and lower the free energy change of the rate determining step. As a further expansion to the family of SACs, double-atom catalysts (DACs) have emerged as a novel frontier in heterogeneous catalysis [144,145]. Double-atom catalysts can be regarded as a supported metal catalyst exclusively containing dual-metal atom sites on the surface of substrate [146]. With potential defects, high atom-utilization efficiency and unique electronic structures, DACs are also predicted to be a promising candidate for boosting the electrocatalytic NRR performance [147–150]. Especially, the synergistic effect between adjacent active sites could tune the adsorption behavior of intermediates in NRR and promote their catalytic activity [151–153]. By a combination of experiments and DFT calculations, Li and coworkers designed atomic Fe and Mo metal dimer in situ anchored on defect-rich graphene layers (FeMo@NG) and demonstrated their outstanding NRR performances [154]. Owing to the synergistic effect of the bimetal active sites, ligand, as well as geometric effects, the obtained FeMo@NG with numerous FeMoN x C active sites achieved a high Faradaic efficiency of 41.7% at −0.2 V and high ammonia production rate of 14.95 µg h−1 mg−1 at −0.4 V vs. RHE, which are significantly higher than its single-atom counterparts (Fe@NG and Mo@NG). DFT calculations further elucidated that the FeMoN6 acted as active sites, which could not only weaken the NN triple bond but also lower the NRR energy barrier, contributing to an enhanced electrocatalytic activity. A summary of the above literature shows that the NRR single-atom catalysts reported so far mainly include Ru, Au, Mo, Fe Cu, Ni and Mn-SAs anchored by M−N x on the N-containing carbon support. In addition, for all reported cases the carbon support is entirely produced by the carbonization of MOFs or organic molecules. These methods are not suitable for the preparation of SACs with high yield and controllable quality. Therefore, there is an urgent need to enrich the SACs family by exploring new coordination bonds, which can not only fix SACs on the support, but also induce new catalytically active structures with excellent catalytic activity. 3.4 Crystal facet Crystal facets can affect the adsorption and activation of N2 and intermediates on the catalyst surface, and rational adjustment of exposed specific facets can optimize active sites and enhance electrocatalytic performance [155,156]. Especially, high-index facets, which are generally described by a set of Miller indices {hkl} with at least one index greater than unity, can offer more high-activity sites for various reactions [157]. These facets, possessing a high density of exposed low-coordinated atoms, usually exhibit significantly enhanced activities than that of the low-index facets [158]. From this point of view, several researches focusing on various Au nanostructures were reported for electrochemical NRR [159,160]. As a proof-of-concept paradigm, Yan and coworkers synthesized tetrahexahedral gold nanorods (THH Au NRs) enclosed by high-index crystal {730} facet, which composed of (210) and (310) sub-facets [159]. In 0.1 M KOH solution, the THH Au NRs endowed the electrocatalytic NRR with a large NH3 yield (1.648 μg h−1 cm−2) and high FE (~4.0%) at −0.2 V vs. RHE. As illustrated in DFT calculations, the exposed (210) and (310) facets in the catalyst are favorable for the formation of an unsaturated coordination environment, thereby promoting the adsorption of N2 molecules on the stepped crystal facet, which is beneficial to the subsequent protonation process. Chen and coworkers systematically elucidate the relationship between Au crystal facets and NRR performance [160]. They successfully synthesized well-defined polyhedral Au nanocrystals encased by {100}, {111}, {110}, {310}, {311}, {321}, and {331} monofacets as the electrocatalysts for NRR at ambient conditions (Fig. 8 a). It was found that Au polyhedra encased by high-index facets catalytically outperform those with low-index facets. In 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, the Au nanostars (NSs) enclosed by Au {321} facets reached an NH3 yield of 2.6 μg h−1mg−2 at −0.2 V vs. RHE with Faradaic efficiency of 10.2%, which were 3.2 and 5.1 times higher than those of Au nanocubes (NCs) enclosed by Au {100} facets, respectively. It should be noted that high-index faceted nanocrystals are thermodynamically unstable owing to high surface energy, leading to the unsatisfactory catalytic stability. As depicted in Fig. 8b, during nine cycle tests at −0.2 V vs. RHE, Au NSs showed a stable current density throughout the process, confirming the outstanding stability of Au NSs catalyst. Further theoretical investigation was conducted to provide insights into reaction pathways (Fig. 8c). As revealed in the DFT calculations, high-index Au (321) and (310) facets exhibited a higher energy barrier for H+ reduction (ΔG H*) than low-index (110) and (100) facets, which was conductive to NRR selectivity due to suppression of the competitive HER process. Furthermore, compared to those low-index facets, Au (321) possessed a lower energy barrier for formation of N2H2* on the catalyst surface as well as a larger energy barrier for decomposing the formed N2H2* back into N2 and 2H*, thereby achieving remarkable NRR performance. This work not only disclosed the facet-dependence of Au-based catalysts but also gave critical insights into the rational design of metal nanocrystals for e-NRR. However, the controllable synthesis of metal nanocrystals with high-index facets and in-depth exploration of the effects on the reaction mechanisms for e-NRR are still in their infancy. It is necessary to pay more attention to the development of effective NRR electrocatalysts enclosed by high-index facets. 3.5 Amorphization To improve the catalytic activity of e-NRR, designing amorphous catalysts in a metastable state with under-coordinated dangling bonds and defective sites has attracted increasing attention. For example, Yan and coworkers synthesized the amorphous Au NPs with average size of ~ 5 nm anchored on bisubstrate of CeO x -induced graphite oxide (a-Au/CeO x -RGO) by a facile coreduction method [161]. The designed a-Au/CeO x -RGO hybrid catalyst achieved a high Faradaic efficiency of 10.10% and ammonia yield of 8.3 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at −0.2 V versus RHE, outperforming that of the crystalline counterpart (c-Au/RGO). Notably, CeO x played a critical role in the formation of amorphous Au NPs while 2D RGO sheets served as the substrate to homogeneous disperse the Au NPs. Compared with its crystalline counterpart, the amorphous one possessed much more structural distortion and had a much higher concentration of active sites, thus significantly enhancing the catalytic activity for the electrochemical N2 reduction. Yu and coworkers designed a noble-metal-free Bi4V2O11/CeO2 hybrid with an amorphous phase (BVC-A) as the cathode for e-NRR [162]. Similar to the function in the preparation of a-Au/CeO x -RGO, the introduction of CeO2 played a critical role in inducing the amorphous structure of Bi4V2O11. Along with the benefits of amorphization, introducing CeO2 will also establish band alignment with amorphous Bi4V2O11, which could be conductive to interfacial charge transfer. Moreover, the disordered structure of amorphous Bi4V2O11 could provide high density of defective sites and reduce the energy barrier, giving rise to an effective N2 fixation. Attributed to these advantages, the BVC-A exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic NRR performance with ammonia yield of 23.21 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and corresponding Faradaic efficiency of 10.16% under ambient conditions, surpassing the Bi4V2O11/CeO2 hybrid with crystalline phase (BVC-C) counterpart. Yu and coworkers synthesized amorphous BiNi alloy (a-BiNi) with a 3D interconnected nanoporous framework via a polymer gel-derived method toward significantly enhanced NRR performance (Fig. 9 a) [163]. The amorphous characteristics of the alloy catalyst were verified (Fig. 9b and c) by the results of XRD and TEM. The catalytic mechanism was further investigated by DFT simulations (Fig. 9d). It was found that Bi-metal cannot adsorb molecular N2 at any site, while BiNi alloys enable the strong adsorption of N2. The stronger binding ability of N2 on BiNi alloy were favorable for N2 molecules’ activation. Meanwhile, the free energy diagram showed that the introduction of Ni atoms significantly reduced the energy barrier in the rate determining step (the process of protonation of adsorbed nitrogen *N2 to generate *NNH) and further activates N2. Compared with pure metals, BiNi alloys can not only adjust the adsorption behavior of nitrogen, but also improve the electron transport. Compared with Bi, the shifts of typical XPS Bi 4f peaks to lower binding energies, indicating that there is a charge transfer from Ni to Bi. In the case of similar crystallinity, alloys have lower resistance and faster charge transfer than single-component metals, which is conducive to the improvement of NRR kinetics and efficiency. Notably, the amorphization engineered phase with disordered atom arrangement and defect-rich surface can provide high surface areas with plentiful active sites for N2 adsorption. In addition, the 3D interconnected porous scaffold with high structural stability against structure collapse alleviates the issues of particle aggregation upon cycling, allowing stable and efficient activity of amorphous alloy NRR catalysts for potential practical use. Ascribed to the chemisorption of N2 and the lower ΔG *NNH after the Ni-substitution, and the amorphous feature of alloy framework, a-BiNi exhibited the superior electrocatalytic performance with the maximum FE of 13.8 % and NH3 yield of 17.5 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M Na2SO4. This work offers new insights into optimizing the adsorption energy of reactants and intermediates as well as tuning the crystallinity of NRR electrocatalysts. Amorphous metallic sulfides have recently emerged as a fascinating catalyst for improving the catalytic activity of e-NRR by virtue of the abundant unsaturated coordination sites and surface-exposed defects such as sulfur vacancies. For example, Chu and co-workers successfully prepared amorphous MoS3 with abundant sulfur vacancies as an efficient and durable electrocatalyst for e-NRR, which exhibited an NH3 yield of 51.7 μg h−1 mg−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 12.8% at −0.3 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M LiClO4 [164]. DFT calculations revealed that S vacancies involved in amorphous MoS3 acted as the catalytic centers that could effectively activate N2, reduce the energetics barrier and simultaneously inhibit the HER. Aside from sulfides, transition-metal diborides (TMB2) have been highlighted as a potential candidate for e-NRR. As reported by Chu’s group, amorphous FeB2 porous nanosheets (a-FeB2 PNSs) exhibited superior electrocatalytic NRR performance with average ammonia yield of 39.8 μg h−1 mg−1 (−0.3 V) and Faradaic efficiency of 16.7% (−0.2 V) at ambient conditions, considerably outperforming their crystalline counterpart [165]. DFT calculations disclosed that the disordered structure of amorphous FeB2 could induce the up-shift of the d-band center to enhance the stabilization of key *N2H intermediate, which can reduce the reaction barrier, serving as a trigger to facilitate the NRR process. 4 Interface regulation 4.1 Metal(derivatives)-metal oxide interface Previous investigations have widely demonstrated that the metal–metal oxide interface plays a vital role in improving catalytic activity due to their strong interfacial interaction. Particularly, the interface confinement effect between metals and metal oxides provided and stabilized highly active sites for molecular activation such as CO oxidation, ethanol oxidation, and CO2 reduction [166–168]. In the light of the above, regulation of the fabrication of a metal–metal oxide interface is a feasible and effective way to tackle dynamic issues during the e-NRR process. Au-based nanomaterials possessing excellent electrochemical property have been developed as promising NRR catalyst. For example, Huang and co-workers successfully prepared heterogeneous Au-Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) via a simple one-pot wet-chemical method, which exhibited excellent NRR performance with a high yield of 21.42 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and a favorable Faradaic efficiency of 10.54% at −0.2 V vs. RHE [169]. It was found that Au-Fe3O4 NPs possessed higher yield rate and FE than those of the Au NPs, Fe3O4 NPs, as well as core@shell Au@Fe3O4 NPs for NH3 production under ambient conditions. To further investigate the intrinsic reason for excellent catalytic activity for Au-Fe3O4 NPs, they performed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy for all prepared catalysts. It was found that the Au-Fe3O4 NPs had abundant Au-O bond, which enhanced the binding strength of the catalyst for the reactants and intermediates. Additionally, compared with other catalysts, the Au-Fe3O4 NPs had obvious binding energy shift at Au 4f spectra, demonstrating the higher tendency of electron transfer, which attributed to the strong charge transfer capability of the Au-Fe3O4 NPs caused by the unique heterostructure. N2 temperature-programmed desorption characterization also indicated that the unique heterojunction structure effectively enhanced the N2 chemisorption, leading to better NRR performance. They further carried out theoretical calculations to support the experimental characterizations and provide a theoretical insight into the reaction mechanism. They found that Fe atoms were active sites to fix N2 into *N2H, while the introduction of Au atoms could weaken the adsorption of *NH x intermediates after the first ammonia formation. Due to the unique synergistic effects, the Au-Fe3O4 could optimize the strong N2 adsorption and N x H y intermediates desorption, making NRR pathway along an energetic-favorable process and ensuring a better NRR performance. Xu and co-workers obtained Au/WO3− x by designing Au nanoparticles (NPs) grown on defective WO3− x [170]. Both the experimental results and theoretical calculations indicated that electron transfer between the Au nanoparticles and defective WO3− x promoted the N2 molecules dynamic activation. Thus, the prepared electrocatalyst has a large NH3 yield of 23.15 μg h−1 mg−1, with a FE of 14.72% at −0.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KOH. Li and coworkers prepared ZrO2 and carbon wrapped Au (Au/ZrO2) with highly dispersed Au distribution as efficient e-NRR catalyst [171]. The interaction between Au and ZrO2 could facilitate electron transfer from ZrO2 substrate to Au, which modified the electronic structure of Au, therefore reduced the activation energy for reductive protonation of *N2 (the rate limiting step of e-NRR), resulting in a superior e-NRR performance. Benefiting from the metal–metal oxide interactions, the optimal Au/ZrO2 catalyst showed a high ammonia yield of 54.84 μg h−1 mgAu −1 and a FE of 6.51% at −0.2 V vs. RHE. Liang and co-workers developed PdO/Pd heterojunctions supported on carbon nanotubes (PdO/Pd/CNTs), which exhibited good NRR activity comparable to PdO/CNTs [172]. The results showed that the abundant PdO-Pd interfaces can act as active sites for promoting the activation of N2 molecules and proton transitions. The Pd phase preferentially adsorbed nitrogen gas to form stable chemisorbed Pd-N2 bonds, while the PdO phase transmitted protons to form α-PdH and broke the NN triple bond. The synergistic effect of Pd and PdO efficiently shorten the transmission pathway of protons and reduce the overpotential of the chemical reaction. Thus, the electrocatalyst with abundant PdO-Pd interface showed highly efficient and robust electrocatalytic performance for the NRR. When tested in 0.1 M KOH, it exhibited a high FE of 11.5% and a NH3 yield up to 18.2 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at 0.1 V vs. the RHE. Ding and coworkers prepared a novel heterojunction of C@CoS@TiO2 through coordination-driven epitaxial growth [173]. The CoS nanosheets are uniformly anchored on individual TiO2 nanofibers to form a double-active heterojunction (Fig. 10 a). On the one hand, the TiO2 nanofibrous membrane can uniformly confine the CoS nanosheets against agglomeration, thus preserving the active sites. On the other hand, the intimate coupling between CoS and TiO2 enables facile charge transfer, thereby inducing fast reaction kinetics at the heterointerface. The obtained C@CoS@TiO2 material achieved a high FE of 28.6% with a NH3 yield rate of 8.09 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited high long-term electrochemical stability. As illustrated in Fig. 10(b), the chronoamperometry curve is very stable during the whole 12 h electrolysis process. Both the ammonia yield and the Faradaic efficiency suffered slight reduction after 12 h electrolysis, indicating superior long-term durability of the C@CoS@TiO2 nanofibrous membrane (Fig. 10c). Besides, the whole catalyst structure is identical to that before electrolysis (Fig. 10d). 4.2 Metal (derivatives)-carbon material interface Incorporating metal (metal derivatives) catalysts with carbon-based materials to form delicately engineered interface has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing the NRR performance. Graphitic supports have received substantial interests in catalysis due to their unique d-π interaction with transition-metal nanoparticles and other compounds [174]. Chu and coworkers prepared a hybrid catalyst of MoO2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (MoO2/RGO) to catalyze the e-NRR under ambient conditions [175]. In 0.1 M Na2SO4, the as-prepared MoO2/RGO catalyst exhibited excellent performance with an NH3 yield of 37.4 μg h−1 mg−1 and a FE of 6.6% at −0.35 V vs. RHE. DFT calculations revealed that MoO2/RGO hybridization can optimize the structural and electronic properties of MoO2 and reduce energy barrier for *N2H formation, which lead to enhanced reaction kinetics and improved NRR performance. Xie and coworkers synthesized a strong-coupled CoS x /NS-G hybrids via in situ growing cobalt sulfides nanoparticles on a graphene sheet [176]. Detailed characterization demonstrated that the construction of strong Co–N/S–C bridging bonds at the interface between CoS x nanoparticles and graphene support accelerated the reaction kinetics by serving as an electron transport channel, enabling improved NRR performance. Graphdiyne (GDY), a novel 2D carbon allotrope, has received increasing interests recently due to their unique porous structure, uneven-distributed surface charge, superior conductivity and electrochemical stability, which leads to versatile applications in catalysis. Particularly, GDY can be grown on appropriate substrates and the generated interfaces with improved charge transfer and active site could substantially enhance the overall catalytic activities and stabilities in the electrocatalysis. Li and coworkers reported a self-standing 3D GDY/Co2N cathode by in situ growing graphdiyne nanosheet arrays (GDY NAs) on the surface of cobalt nitride nanowires (Co2N NWs) with highly active and selective interface for the e-NRR [177]. DFT calculations indicated that the interface-bonded GDY could contribute a unique p-electronic character to reasonably modify the Co-N compound surface bonding and promote the charge transfer between metal species and GDY, thereby exhibiting superior electronic activity for e-NRR catalysis at the interface. The as-prepared GDY/Co2N cathode featured high selectivity and efficiency for NH3 synthesis in both acidic and neutral conditions. Particularly in acidic conditions, the designed electrocatalyst exhibited a record of NH3 yield of 219.72 μg h−1 mg−1 and corresponding FE of 58.60% at room temperature and atmospheric pressure, outperforming the previously reported electrocatalysts. Besides, such excellent catalytic performances can be maintained over 114 h with negligible decrease. This work is promising to generate new concepts and drive rapid development in the field of NRR. Additionally, it is demonstrated that the hybridization of g-C3N4 and compound nanoparticles can realize enhanced NRR activity. Tian and coworkers synthesized a 2D/2D MoS2/C3N4 heterostructure as NRR catalyst [178]. In 0.1 M LiClO4 solution, the electrocatalyst possesses a high FE of 17.8% and a NH3 yield of 18.5 μg h−1 mg−1, which far exceeded the individual MoS2 or C3N4 component. DFT calculations revealed that the MoS2-C3N4 interfacial coupling interaction played an essential role in enhancing the NRR activity. The efficient interface coupling interaction between MoS2 and C3N4 could not only improve the stabilization of *N2H intermediate on Mo edge sites of MoS2 but also protect the e-NRR-active Mo edge sites from the competing HER and leading to a high FE. 4.3 Intermetallic compounds The rational design of intermetallic compounds is advantageous for the construction of new heterogeneous NRR catalysts due to its superior modification of the charge states for N2 activation, strong stability accomplished by implanting active sites into the lattice framework, relatively simple structures that allow study of the mechanism by theoretical calculations [179]. Due to the novel synergy effects between different metals on electronic and geometric structures, the use of intermetallics shows great potential for regulating the e-NRR activity and selectivity [180]. Recently, intermetallic compounds have been widely used in the field of electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction, and the most commonly studied are Pd-based [181–185], Au-based [186–189], and Ru-based [190,191] alloys. For example, Huang and co-workers obtained structurally ordered body-centered cubic (BCC) PdCu nanoparticles by annealing face-centered cubic (FCC) PdCu in Ar/H2 atmosphere and exhibited high efficiency and selective towards e-NRR [181]. At the annealing temperature of 350 °C, the structure of PdCu nanoparticles completely changed from the FCC phase to the BCC phase, as confirmed by the XRD and HRTEM characterization (Fig. 11 a–d). This phase transformation would lead to an upshift of d-band center, which enhanced the binding ability of BCC PdCu to nitrogen molecules and intermediates (Fig. 11e). Further DFT calculations revealed that strong d-d coupling between Pd and neighboring Cu sites in BCC PdCu bridges the electron-transfer coulomb gap and boosts transfer activities for efficient NRR catalysis. The energetic trends showed that the NRR pathway on the BCC PdCu is the most energetically favorable with an energetic barrier lower than that of FCC PdCu (Fig. 11f). In 0.5 M LiCl, the as-prepared BCC PdCu achieved a high ammonia production rate of 35.7 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and a Faraday efficiency of 11.5% at −0.1 V verse RHE, which was much higher than that of the FCC PdCu. Guo and co-workers designed 3D hierarchical interconnected porous bimodal PdCu alloys with tailored Pd/Cu atomic ratios as efficient NRR catalysts [182]. The Pd3Cu1 alloy with optimized Pd/Cu atomic ratios exhibited a high NH3 yield rate of 39.9 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and corresponding Faradaic efficiency of 1.22%. Due to the structural integrity, the Pd3Cu1 alloy endowed an excellent stability, showing no obvious changes in the current density, yield rate and FE within 6th consecutive tests. Most importantly, the tailored atomic ratio of Cu (HER-poor) over Pd (NRR-favorable) could be favorable for NRR catalytic behaviors and inhibit competitive HER. Similarly, Zhang and co-workers successfully prepared bimetallic Pd1Ag1 alloys with optimized Pd/Ag atomic ratios and hierarchical porous structure via a two-step dealloying process [183]. Combining the merits of rich low-coordinated surface atoms, enhanced reactant accessibility and accelerated interfacial electron transfer kinetics, the Pd1Ag1 alloys showed superior catalytic activity towards the e-NRR compare to Pd1Ag2 and Pd3Ag1 alloys. Based on the above research, it is an effective strategy to further improve the e-NRR performance of noble metals by alloying noble metals with appropriate transition metals, in which the introduction of a second element could enhance catalytic activities of noble metals by changing its geometric and/or electronic structures. Additionally, considering the scarcity and high price of noble metals, the cost of the catalyst will be greatly reduced if the introduced metal is cheap. As one may know, Au possesses suitable electronic structure that facilitates charge transfer and protonation of the reaction intermediate. Besides, the weak affinity of Au to H can effectively suppress the competition reaction of HER. In addition to Pd-based alloy, Au-based materials are promising candidates for the electrosynthesis of NH3 from N2. Wang and coworkers synthesized bimetallic mesoporous Au3Rh film on nickel foam (mAu3Rh/NF) through a micelle-assisted replacement method [186]. In 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte, the as-prepared mAu3Rh/NF achieved a high NH3 yield of 26.29 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and Faraday efficiency of 23.84%, which is much better than other compounds with different Au/Rh ratios. The synergistic effect of the Au-Rh alloy structure can promote the adsorption of N2, resulting in the enhanced NRR performance. Zhang and coworkers prepared Ag2Au1 nanotubes via galvanic replacement reaction for e-NRR [187]. DFT calculations revealed that the introduction of the negative ion featured Au atoms in the Ag2Au1 alloy is conductive for the adsorption and activation of N2. Benefit from the integrated structure, the Ag2Au1 nanotubes showed excellent stable ammonia yield rate and faradaic efficiency up to 18 h. Li and coworkers presented a powerful strategy to significantly enhance the Faradaic efficiency of Au electrocatalysts [188]. They successfully prepared highly coupled Au and Ni nanoparticles dispersed on/in nitrogen-doped carbon supports. Both the experimental and theoretical results indicated that the unique donor–acceptor couples generated from the Au and Ni nanoparticles played a vital role in facilitating the adsorption and activation of molecular N2. In 0.05 M H2SO4 electrolyte, the as-prepared Au6/Ni reached a remarkably high Faradaic efficiency of 67.8% at −0.14 V vs. RHE. The Ru-based catalysts with the best catalytic performance in the traditional Haber Bosch process have also been extensively studied [192]. Because they are considered to have the most ideal equilibrium relationship between nitrogen adsorption and intermediates desorption. Gao and coworkers prepared fusiform-like ruthenium-copper alloy nanosheets (RuCu-FNs) and utilized them for the e-NRR at room temperature under ambient conditions [190]. In 0.1 M HCl electrolyte, the RuCu-FNs exhibited a high faradaic efficiency FE of 7.2% and an average NH3 yield rate of 53.6 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 at −0.10 V vs. RHE, outperforming the corresponding non-metallic catalyst and most alloy catalysts. The improved NRR performance was ascribed to alloy engineering, which introduced a second catalytic site for achieving both efficient adsorptive activation of N2 molecules and intermediate desorption from the electrocatalyst surface. Chen and coworkers synthesized Ru88Pt12 nanowires via the controlled engineering of Ru nanowires with atomic Pt decoration [191]. Notably, the designed Ru88Pt12 nanowires showed a high NH3 yield rate of 47.1 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and Faradaic efficiency of 8.9% at −0.2 V verse RHE under ambient conditions. As demonstrated by DFT investigations, the d-band center of Ru is upshifted by the tensile strain induced after the introduction of Pt into the lattice, which not only enhanced N2 adsorption but also improved the selective stabilization of N2H*, resulting in highly efficient NRR electrocatalysis. 4.4 Gas-electrolyte-catalyst interface In addition to the nature of electrocatalysts, the performance of electrocatalysis is also under the influence of the interface between gas, electrolyte and catalysts [62]. Via deliberately designing the near-interface environments such as controlling the hydrophobic/hydrophilic or anaerobic/aerophilic properties of catalysts, enhancing the gas utilization, altering the types of ions in electrolyte, the electrocatalysis performance could be rationally build up [193,194]. These methods have resulted in electrocatalysts that achieved superior performances in ORR and CO2RR [67]. Moreover, current e-NRR progress is greatly inhibited by overwhelming competition from the HER across all traditional NRR catalysts, leaving an unsatisfactory selectivity toward N2 fixation. To settle the major obstacle, one of the attractive strategies is to explore a gas-diffusion layer to provide an effective gas-diffusion pathway and impede water absorption at the catalyst surface. By rationally engineering surface hydrophobicity, the gas/liquid/solid (gas/electrolyte/catalyst) triphase interface can be optimized, since the hydrophobic surfaces of catalysts can manipulate the proton activity with suppressed hydrogen evolution reactions. Inspired by these discoveries, several researches have been reported in the NRR field. Ling and coworkers successfully obtained ZIF-coated Ag-Au platform (Ag-Au@ZIF) as an efficient NRR electrocatalyst by coating a superhydrophobic metal–organic framework (MOF) layer over the NRR electrocatalyst, in which the MOF shell can inhibit the access of water molecules to the encapsulated active surfaces, thereby weakening hydrogen evolution [195]. With the advantage of high gas adsorptivity, the MOF layer can also enrich N2 concentrations directly at the active surfaces. Significantly, a high FE (~18%, 2-fold that of Ag-Au) and NH3 yield (~10 pmol s−1 cm−2, 4-fold that of Ag-Au) for the NRR over Ag-Au@ZIF is obtained. In addition, the catalyst exhibited an excellent long-term stability. Similarly, Du and coworkers reported the design of a core–shell nanostructured NPG@ZIF-8 by encapsulating nanoporous gold (NPG) in a superhydrophobic zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 [196]. The designed electrocatalytic systems can not only suppress the HER but also facilitate the concentration of N2 molecules near the active sites. A highest Faradaic efficiency of 44% and a significantly boosted of ammonia production rate of 28.7 μg h−1 cm−2 were achieved over the composite, as well as an electrochemical stability and selectivity (98%) toward NRR. Shen and coworkers designed a novel aerophilic-hydrophilic heterostructured electrode for efficient e-NRR under ambient conditions via applying aerophilic ultrathin porous Bi5O7I nanotubes (UP-BOINs) and hydrophilic carbon spheres, which provided an enlarged and abundant three-phase boundary (solid–liquid-gas) [197]. Due to the special aerophilic-hydrophilic heterostructure, it simultaneously provides abundant H+ on the reaction surface, accelerates the N2 accumulation on the aerophilic site, and facilitates the gas release on the hydrophilic site, thereby improving the NRR performance. Particularly, the positively charged aerophilic UP-BOINs were introduced into the electrolyte, which could not only bring N2 from gas feed to cathode but also act as a cocatalyst to facilitate the NRR process. As a paradigm, benefiting from the functionalized electrolyte, the NH3 yield is boosted from 7.96 to 31.46 mg h−1 m−2 and the Faradaic efficiency is increased from 5.19% to 13.42% at −0.4 V versus RHE 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution. Wang and coworkers designed a unique aerophilic-hydrophilic heterostructure Si-based catalyst for photoelectrochemical synthesis of ammonia [198]. To simultaneously weaken hydrogen evolution and enhance the diffusion of N2 to the surface, hydrophobic porous poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) framework was introduced on the surface of the Si-based photocathode (Fig. 12 a). Au nanoparticles acting as active sites was highly dispersed on the 3D porous PTFE structure (Fig. 12b). Compared with the Au/Si photocathode surface, the Au-PTFE/Si-based photocathode surface showed obvious hydrophobic (electrolyte) and affinity (N2) behavior. The aerophilic 3D porous PTFE structure provided a high N2 concentration on the photocathode surface. At the same time, Au NPs on the PTFE framework showed excellent catalytic activity to N2 reduction. Further DFT calculations revealed that such unique heterostructure reduced the energy barrier for the nitrogen reduction reaction (Fig. 12c). When tested in 0.05 M H2SO4 with 0.05 M Na2SO3 electrolyte under 1 sun illumination, the maximum yield rate of NH3 and the faradic efficiency were 18.9 μg h−1 cm−2 and 37.8% achieved on Au-PTFE/TS, respectively (Fig. 12e). These findings provide us a stimulus to explore a new scheme for artificial ammonia synthesis under ambient conditions. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Ammonia synthesis is one of the most important industrial processes. The product is not only a versatile industrial raw material, but also an ideal clean energy carrier. Traditional Haber-Bosch process consumes numerous energies and emits lots of greenhouse gases, which is deviating from the goal of “carbon neutrality” nowadays. Therefore, it is very important to develop green and sustainable alternatives. Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction can achieve high-efficiency, low-energy consumption, and zero-emission synthesis of ammonia under mild conditions, and has received extensive attention in recent year. However, the e-NRR is severely impeded by the low active site density and sluggish kinetics. To achieve a substantial increase in selectivity and activity, it is critical to rationally design and develop new and efficient catalysts. In this review, the basic thermodynamics and mechanism of N2 reduction reaction have been presented. Based on the strategies of rationally tuning the catalyst activity, recent advances in emerging NRR electrocatalysts are systematically summarized with emphasis on the defect and interface engineering. Despite the significant progress observed for advanced electrocatalysts, it is still challenging to in-depth characterize and understand the defect/interface effects in some cases. It is worth noting that the defects and interfaces can change dynamically during electrocatalytic process. For instance, defect engineering is frequently considered to induce a large amount of metastable sites, which are expected to be dynamically transformed during the catalytic reaction. Therefore, it is crucial to study the unstable defects as well as the real active sites. The development of in-situ characterizations to explore the state of defect during catalytic process is of great significance to reveal the real catalytic process and reaction pathway, providing a better understanding of the essence of defect-driven NRR electrocatalysis. On the basis of an in-depth apprehend of the mechanism, we believe that more effective electrocatalyst could be developed to boost the N2 reduction activity. On the whole, although a lot of attempts and great progress have been made, the electrochemical synthesis of ammonia is still in the infancy stage. The reported NRR electrocatalysts activity cannot meet the requirements of industrial applications and need to be further improved. To accomplish e-NRR that is close to practical use, the following aspects should be considered: (1) Rigorous control experiments for reliable e-NRR measurements. In recent years, the electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis has developed rapidly, and various electrocatalysts and electrocatalytic systems have been continuously developed and reported. The record on yield and Faraday efficiency was constantly broken and updated. However, due to the extremely low yield and efficiency of ammonia in e-NRR at present, it is extremely vulnerable to pollution such as ammonia and nitrogen-containing species that are ubiquitous in the external environment. With the continuous discovery of deficiencies, establishing a benchmarking protocols for reliable NRR measurements is urgent to ensure the repeatability of the research.
