Therefore, rigorous control experiments are highly recommended especially using isotope measurements with 15N2 to trace the N-source of the generated NH3. Moreover, it is recommended that researchers should provide all experimental details when publishing their work to guarantee the reproducibility and establish the solid grounds required for this emerging field to develop. (2) Selection of appropriate benchmarking catalysts toward e-NRR. As known, commercially available electrocatalysts such as Pt/C, RuO2, and IrO2 are wildly used as the benchmarking catalyst in HER, ORR, and OER. However, at present, there is still no benchmarking catalyst in NRR. It is difficult for researchers to evaluate whether the current system is scientific and reliable, which lead to the situation where a large number of the results are unreliable and difficult to reproduce. Note that only reliable results can contribute to the screening of catalysts and promote the progress of e-NRR. To achieve meaningful results, benchmarking catalysts toward e-NRR are urgently required so that the researchers could check whether the observed experiment performance is in line with the literature data. (3) In-depth understanding of the e-NRR mechanism. Theoretical calculations such as DFT together with molecular dynamics (MD) simulations have been demonstrated as powerful tools to provide new insights into the reaction mechanisms and pathways. A thorough understanding of the mechanism is of great significance for the rational design of new and efficient catalysts. Based on the theoretical explorations, the potential active sites of electrocatalysts, the energy barriers of corresponding rate-limiting steps, the feasible reaction pathways accompanying with least energy input, and the required overpotential for driving the reaction could be efficiently revealed. (4) State-of-the-art in situ characterization techniques for e-NRR. To date, most of the current researches regarding the reaction mechanism are still limited to simple explanation according to theoretical calculations, and the reports on the experimental detection of reaction intermediate species are relatively limited. From this point of view, the high-level in situ or in operando characterization techniques will shed light on the in-depth relationship between reaction activity and the important limiting parameters as well as the dynamic changes occurring on the catalyst surface during electrochemical reactions. For instance, in situ DRIFTS and quasi in situ XPS measurements could be employed to determine the reaction intermediates and their interactions with catalysts during the NRR process. With the development of advanced in-situ technology, in-depth exploration of the reaction mechanism can be conducted to provide further guidance for rational optimization of the catalyst. (5) Coupling multiple strategies for efficient electrocatalysts. Compared with other electrochemical reactions, the types of catalysts currently reported by NRR are relatively few. The research on new electrocatalysts is still an exciting field. The combination of multiple catalyst design strategies, such as vacancies and heteroatom doping, vacancies and structural regulation, vacancies and amorphization, enables the novel synergetic effects, thereby promoting preferential NRR electrocatalysis. (6) Multi-step nitrogen-to-ammonia fixation. At present, one-step electrochemical nitrogen reduction is limited due to the low selectivity to ammonia as well as tough activation of N2 together with its poor solubility in aqueous solutions. Notably, multi-step nitrogen-to-ammonia fixation with one problem effectively solved in each step is recently emerging as an up-to-date frontier in NRR fields. Especially, research groups from Australia successively reported that two-step N2-to-NH3 fixation can be rationally realized through serially integrating a plasma-driven N2 oxidation to activate N2 with an electrochemical NOx - reduction process to achieve highly selective NH3 production [199,200]. These findings provide a rational paradigm for catalytic nitrogen fixation and encourage us to exploit more alternative process for ammonia production. D ongxue Guo is a doctoral candidate in inorganic chemistry from the College of Chemistry at Nankai University. She obtained her bachelor’s degree in applied chemistry from the College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering at Qingdao University of Science and Technology in 2017. Her current research focuses on electrocatalysts. Shuo Wang received his bachelor’s degree in materials chemistry from Liaoning University in 2019. He is currently pursuing his MS degree at Nankai University. His current research focuses on photocatalysis. Jun Xu received his PhD degree from Western University in 2014. He then worked as a postdoctoral fellow at University of California, Berkeley, from 2014 to 2017. He has been an associate professor at Nankai University, China, since 2018. His main research interest is focused on solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Wenjun Zheng received his BS (1982), and PhD (1996) degrees at Jilin University and worked as a postdoctoral fellow at University of Science and Technology of China from 1996–1998. He has been a full Professor in College of Chemistry at Nankai University, China, since 2000. His main research interest is focused on supercapacitors, lithium ion batteries, photocatalysis and sensors. Danhong Wang received her MS degree from College of Chemistry at Nankai University in 1997 and her PhD degree from Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology in 2002. She then worked as a postdoctoral fellow at Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology from 2002 to 2004. She has been an associate professor at Nankai University, China, since 2004. Her main research interest is focused on the nanomaterials for energy and environmental applications.

coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) under ambient conditions is an emerging strategy to tackle the hydrogen- and energy-intensive operations for traditional Haber-Bosch process in industrial ammonia (NH3) synthesis. However, the e-NRR performance is currently impeded by the inherent inertness of N2 molecules, the extremely slow kinetics and the overwhelming competition from the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), all of which cause unsatisfied yield and ammonia selectivity (Faradaic efficiency, FE). Defect and interface engineering are capable of achieving novel physical and chemical properties as well as superior synergistic effects for various electrocatalysts. In this review, we first provide a general introduction to the NRR mechanism. We then focus on the recent progress in defect and interface engineering and summarize how defect and interface can be rationally designed and functioned in NRR catalysts. Particularly, the origin of superior NRR catalytic activity by applying these approaches was discussed from both theoretical and experimental perspectives. Finally, the remaining challenges and future perspectives in this emerging area are highlighted. It is expected that this review will shed some light on designing NRR electrocatalysts with excellent activity, selectivity and stability.
